author: perama
content:
One of the questions that will help wallets decide on their logic is: How much and how often does the base fee rise?

Or, to reword this: If I set a max fee as some multiple of the base fee, how often will this become non-viable in the near future?

I took a look at that question, with combinations of base fee multiples in range 1.3-3x and time windows 30-240s. For each block I generated a fee (`base_fee * multiple`) and selected the latest mined block in the specified window. 

I called a multiple 'non-viable' if the final mined block in some interval (e.g. 30s) had a base fee greater than the multiple.

That is to say, regardless of what the base fee did during the window, the multiple was considered viable if it the transaction could have been mined using base fee as the only criteria. The priority fee is excluded from all calculations.

The result was that the multiple was viable in the range 97.7%-100% of the time, details and data in the link.

https://gist.githubusercontent.com/perama-v/d23a8d7a446fe8b235889d1a896ab9a2/raw/e3d8e3c51ed5bc156b3d40ac2539dbd681490033/result.txt

author: andi9314
content: This is really cool. I think it would also be interesting to see how likely it is that a fee slightly lower than the current base fee gets me included in the next x seconds.

author: perama
content: A fee 0.5x current base fee was viable at some point within 30s TBD% of the time.

author: perama
content: The Yin to the Yang

author: perama
content:
The deed is done:

https://gist.github.com/perama-v/4c6b5088b18dfb928e9675f8aca869a5

author: perama
content:
This is a family of curves, it shows two things, based purely on the movement of the base fee with real blocks since the fork:

- If you set a low max fee to save money, what is the 'waiting situation' like?
- If you set a high max fee, what is the 'safety situation' like?

author: perama
content:
Which would be very nice as a Dune dashboard if anyone has the skills and wants to replicate a live version.

```
* Curve 1: 30s
- Curve 2: 90s

100 |      *   *  *  *
    |   *    - - - - -
    | *    -
    | *   -
    |*  -
    | -
     -------------------
   0     b_f_multiple  3

y-axis: cumulative probability
x-axis: base fee multiple.
```

author: perama
content:
I won't try to do too much interpretation of the results, other than to say that:

1. Early data (YMMV)
2. 
- If you try to save money and get in within a few minutes, the base fee to target is ~0.95x, which has enjoyed an 80% chance of viability.
- If you want safety 1.2x base fee has been okay ~92% of the time, and 1.5x 99% of the time. 

This is all for "will the protocol accept the transaction"
As for what miners have been accepting, spot checks have shown miners to be tolerant of 1 nanoether per gwei priority fees.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
in a thread somewhere you were pointing out that basefee essentially prices something that is out-of-date, with an example of blocks that have 1 slot and two users who want in, there was efficiency loss because waiting for basefee to lower would get you in at a better price. definitely agree there is something to explore here, my intuition though is that demand is rather smooth, so in practice I'd expect the efficiency loss to be not so large. it's true too that there is downward pressure on basefee because of the multiplicative rule, but it only leads to the pathological case of basefee to 0 when demand is exactly as large as the 15M target supply

it still looks like it would be a good problem to formalise, thinking something like "if demand at t and demand at t+1 are epsilon close, the efficiency is some small function of epsilon close to optimal efficiency", at least to get clarity on how to compare update/pricing rules with one another

author: barnabemonnot
content: this is very cool. it's hard to build counterfactuals to compare bidding strategies but this seems like a simple approach that gives good insight. in a sense you are looking at whether in hindsight your parameter choice was individually rational or not, as if you were the only one changing your max fee while everyone else keeps it constant. i expect that if we want users to delegate control of the max fee to their wallet the default multiple needs to be viable for a high percentage of outcomes

author: perama
content: Thanks, yes I agree.

author: schone_wizard
content: excuse me if this is exactly an MEV question, because i am slow when it comes to that

author: schone_wizard
content: but am I understanding correctly that the miner of this block received 2ETH?

author: schone_wizard
content: https://etherchain.org/block/0xd91baed0cff173c4ad0568b80887865d13fb51efe5e7aecbb3bcedeef75e2deb

author: schone_wizard
content: if so... post 1559, why shouldn't every miner just mine blocks with no transactions in them?

author: pietjepuk
content:
they can, but if the priority fee is larger than the uncling risk, it's in their own interest to include those transactions
See https://notes.ethereum.org/@barnabe/rk5ue1WF_

author: schone_wizard
content: can you explain that a bit further please?

author: pietjepuk
content: The earlier you broadcast a block, the more likely it is to become the canonical one. Including transactions takes a little work/time, but there's a reward associated with doing so as well (the priority fee).

author: pietjepuk
content: So by including transactions you increase the risk of no longer being the canonical block (uncling), but also increase your tx rewards. There's a trade-off there, which has been worked out in more detail in the link I posted.

author: schone_wizard
content: and that trade off makes it worth more than 2ETH? I guess i'm just surprised that in the case of 0 transactions, we don't burn the base fee still but rather give the whole 2ETH to the miner

author: pietjepuk
content: The 2 ETH is the block reward no? That is related to providing security to the blockchain

author: schone_wizard
content: right but i thought (and that's really my question, cause i'm not sure) that out of the 2ETH+transaction fees we deduct the basefee and burn it

author: schone_wizard
content: and in the link i provided above, it makes it seem 0 was burned, hence the miner getting the full 2ETH

author: pietjepuk
content: yes, because there were no transactions included. No gas used, no `base_fee_per_gas * gas_used` to be burned

author: schone_wizard
content: right, but that seems like a much higher payoff than the one with transactions...

content: example:

author: schone_wizard
content: almost a full block:

author: schone_wizard

author: schone_wizard
content: less risk, more reward

content: again, it's a trade-off

content: would you pick $0.01 off the ground?

author: pietjepuk

author: vagabond2971
content:
on ethresearch, I saw the following statement
> The goal (of 1559) is to make it so a user can submit a transaction with a max fee that is the highest they are willing to pay and be sure that their transaction will be included at the lowest price possible.
how so? what mechanism guarantees the tx will be included at the lowest price possible?

author: vagabond2971
content: https://ethresear.ch/t/eip-1559-is-not-making-fees-predictable/10274/5

author: vagabond2971
content:
to be specific, the tip amount is a fixed value, which in no way guarantees no overpaying
what am I missing?

author: jgm
content: If you set a max base fee of 100Gwei, and the base fee of the block in which the tx is included is 60Gwei, you will be refunded the 40Gwei*gas used

author: vagabond2971
content:
interesting.. but now I'm more confused ðŸ˜„
first, I don't see any mentioning of a refund on the eip 1559 page (maybe I should read it again)
also, does that mean I specify tip == 0 in your case? then who decides the tip amount for me?

author: vagabond2971
content: if there are more txs with tip ==0 than can be fit in a block, who decides who gets in?

author: jgm
content:
The protocol decides which transactions can be put in a block.  Only transactions with base fee >= the block's base fee are eligible for inclusion.

Miners decide which eligible transactions are put in a block.  That is wholly up to them, but usually they go in based on the value of the tip.

author: vagabond2971
content: I think I understand now. so it'll get sorted by (max - base)

author: vagabond2971
content: thank you

author: pietjepuk
content:
```python
# priority fee is capped because the base fee is filled first
priority_fee_per_gas = min(transaction.max_priority_fee_per_gas, transaction.max_fee_per_gas - block.base_fee_per_gas)
# signer pays both the priority fee and the base fee
effective_gas_price = priority_fee_per_gas + block.base_fee_per_gas  
```
That's the part in the spec. Note that `effective_gas_price` can (and often will) be lower than `max_fee_per_gas`. They will be equal if `max_fee_per_gas == max_priority_fee_per_gas`

author: vagabond2971
content: this matches my original understanding. however, in this case there's no guarantee of "lowest price possible"

author: vagabond2971
content: say the base fee is 40G, I set max to be 100G. what priority fee should I set?

author: jacknelson
content: wait so are fees and tip different?

author: jacknelson
content: so now we have fees and tip???

author: pietjepuk
content: See https://notes.ethereum.org/@barnabe/rk5ue1WF_ for why 1-2 Gwei is good enough most of time

author: vagabond2971
content: according to the code, the effective gas will be 40G

author: jacknelson
content: thanks!

author: vagabond2971
content: which doesn't guarantee inclusion even though I'm willing to pay 100G

author: pietjepuk
content: no, the effective gas price will be the base fee (40 Gwei) _plus_ whatever priority fee the user specified, as long as the sum doesn't exceed the max fee per gas the user specified

author: vagabond2971
content: right, but you said 1 right?

author: pietjepuk
content: Yes, that'd be a typical good value to set for the max prioirty fee per gas

author: pietjepuk
content: It's to compensate the miner for the uncling risk, see the link I just posted

author: vagabond2971
content: how does that help me? I'm willing to pay 100G in total. but my eff gas is not 40.000000001G

author: vagabond2971
content: *now

author: vagabond2971
content: I understand the base price can rise

author: pietjepuk
content: Wait, what? If you always want to pay 100 Gwei, set the `max_fee_per_gas` too 100 Gwei, _and_ the `max_priority_fee_per_gas` to 100 Gwei. That's basically the way transactions worked until London

author: vagabond2971
content: correct. so there's nothing "dynamic" about the priority fee. only the base fee is dynamic. right?

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, not entirely. The uncling risk does increase if the value of tx rewards already included in the block gets higher, so the priority fee for additional transactions to include should also be higher. In practice miners are often not _that_ sophisticated

author: pietjepuk
content: and in case of demand exceeding the available block space (2 * gas_target), inclusion of transactions reverts to a first-price auction based on the priority fee of course

author: pietjepuk
content: 50 M gas of tx are eligible (max_fee_per_gas > base_fee), block only fits 30 M, so the miner picks the ones with the highest priority fees. But the expectation is that the number of eligible transactions is often ~15 M gas (and < 30 M gas), and that the base fee is able to adjust to keep it that way.

author: vagabond2971
content: got it. so setting base + 1 _almost_ guarantees inclusion, unless block is full

author: pietjepuk
content: Yep!

author: vagabond2971
content: thanks!

author: pietjepuk
content:
In case the base fee is 40 Gwei, you can just set the `max_priority_fee_per_gas` to 1 Gwei (to compensate the miner for the uncling risk), and the `max_priority_fee_per_gas` to 60 Gwei or something (assuming you are willing to pay that much). 
In many cases you will be included in the next block with 40 Gwei base fee, and you will end up paying 41 Gwei per gas (40 of which is burned, 1 goes to miner). But just in case the block is full, you will be included in the one after (that has a base fee of about 1.125 * 40 = 45 Gwei), and pay 46 Gwei (45 of which is burned, 1 goes to miner).

author: jgm
content: (Much like miners can put in 0-tip transactions to pay their pool, for example, there are always exceptions)

author: potuz
content: Right but that's why I think that priority fee may end up being irrelevant, and therefore the average user should always use 1

author: potuz
content: Since presumably whatever he chooses may not even come into play if mev is orders of magnitude larger

author: jgm
content:
That only matters if MEV takes the entire block gas limit.  If not, then the remaining transactions will be ordered by tip.
(And if so, then the tx won't get in regardless.)

author: potuz
content: How does the stock client, say catalyst, order transactions for inclusion? After the merge, a validator that doesn't run geth-mev, nor grabs his blocks from elsewhere. What algorithm is he using for transaction inclusion? Is it tips? I would have guessed here a FIFO scheme

author: jgm
content: `geth` orders by fee, give or take.  Don't know about the others.
